pageData.alt: Picture showing the transparent upper torso of a human with the bones visible

pageData.text: To maintain a stable internal state, the body must take in oxygen and expel carbon dioxide. The respiratory system facilitates the exchange of atmospheric oxygen with carbon dioxide generated by metabolism. In this investigation, several aspects of the respiratory system will be examined, with special attention to assessment of respiratory function.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes
 Activity 1: Measuring Breathing While at Rest – 10 minutes
 Activity 2: Measuring Breathing While Standing – 10 minutes
 Activity 3: Measuring Breathing After Running – 10 minutes

pageData.title: Note for instructors:
pageData.text: This investigation involves the student providing breathing test results to the instructor as part of the assessment. This is confidential medical information that should not be stored or shared with your health services group or the rest of the class.

pageData.title: Note for students:
pageData.text: The breathing tests performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If your results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Meter stick or tape measure (for measuring height in centimeters)

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Describe the role of the respiratory system in <button className=glossary-text>homeostasis</button>.
Explain the mechanisms of lung ventilation.
Define the various measures of  <button className=glossary-text>lung volume</button> and capacity, and relate them to disorders of the respiratory system.
Observe the effect of a physiological stressor on respiratory function.

pageData.text: Sleep apnea is a category of potentially serious sleep disorders in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts unexpectedly, resulting in poor-quality sleep. Snoring loudly and feeling tired after a full night's sleep are both symptoms of sleep apnea. It is estimated that in the United States, 3-7% of men and 2-5% of women suffer from sleep apnea. Chronic sleep problems can cause obesity, depression, coronary heart disease, weakened immune response, and diabetes.

The most common treatment for sleep apnea is to sleep wearing a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine. This machine pumps a steady flow of oxygen into the airways to prevent them from collapsing, which typically defines sleep apnea disorders. With their airways unobstructed, the patient no longer wakes up repeatedly to resume breathing.

Photo by John Ramspott is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/jramspott/7355393770/

pageData.desc: A dummy head wearing the breathing apparatus for a CPAP machine over its nose and mouth.
pageData.altText: A dummy head wearing the breathing apparatus for a CPAP machine over its nose and mouth.

pageData.text: The respiratory system is responsible for gas exchange — the inhalation of oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) and the exhalation of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>). The lungs, conducting airways, and the diaphragm are key structures of the system.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Respiratory System

pageData.subTitle: Lungs and Diaphragm
pageData.text: Human lungs are sponge-like organs found in the thoracic (chest) cavity. The right lung has 3 lobes and is larger than the bilobed left lung, as the heart occupies more space on the left side. The diaphragm is a domed, sheet-like muscle that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

pageData.subTitle: Breathing
pageData.text:
During inhalation, the diaphragm contracts, and air is pulled through the conducting airways into the lungs.
During exhalation, the diaphragm relaxes, and air is pushed from the lungs.

pageData.subTitle: Bronchi, Bronchioles, and Alveoli
pageData.text: Air enters the lungs from the trachea through the right and left bronchus. These branching airways lead to bronchioles and end in microscopic air sacs called alveoli. The alveoli are the sites of gas exchange between the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.

The body needs energy to survive. The body’s main method of producing energy is through aerobic respiration. In this process, oxygen is used as the oxidizing agent in the chemical process that converts biochemical energy from nutrients into . ATP is the main energy currency of the cell. All physiological processes, from the movement of muscles to DNA production, use ATP. Therefore, the body has a continuous need for oxygen.

While the body is moving, or anytime ATP is expended, carbon dioxide (CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>) is produced as a waste product. CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> dissolves in body fluids and combines with water to form carbonic acid (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>), which quickly dissociates and releases hydrogen ion (H<sub class=bodySubscript>+</sub>) and bicarbonate ion (HCO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub><sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup>). The bicarbonate buffer system is necessary for stabilizing the acid-base balance of the blood. Our body needs to maintain <button className=glossary-text>homeostasis</button>, or the balance between all physiological processes, including maintaining a constant level of chemicals present in the body and maintaining the blood oxygen/carbon dioxide balance in the bloodstream. In short, homeostasis pertains to anything that can unbalance our body and can impact our health, such as an increase in acidity.

Our skin prevents direct gas exchange between the environment and the underlying tissues; therefore, our body utilizes a complex method for oxygen uptake and CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> release. Gases are dissolved into the bloodstream in specialized cells—the <button className=glossary-text>erythrocytes</button>, or red blood cells. These erythrocytes carry a special protein called <button className=glossary-text>hemoglobin</button>. Hemoglobin binds both oxygen and carbon dioxide and carries them throughout the body. Unlike the skin, lung tissue is specialized and permits the direct exchange of gas between the environment and the bloodstream. The difference in concentration between gases in the air and dissolved gases in the blood-stream determines the effectiveness of the gas exchange. The greater the concentration difference is, the faster the gas exchange will be. One way to increase the concentration difference is by quickly transporting the fluid (blood) through the lungs. This will maintain a high dissolved gas difference between the fluid and the air. The most important method for maintaining this difference is the quick ventilation of gases. This prevents the buildup of a layer of gases at different concentrations and increases the speed of gas movement between the air and the body fluid.

To ensure effective gas exchange, the body needs to ventilate the lungs and does so via the process of breathing. Because air always moves from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure, breathing is accomplished by establishing a pressure difference between the air inside the body and the air outside of the body. During inhalation (see Figure 1), also called inspiration, the ribcage is pulled up and out, and the diaphragm is pulled down, increasing  <button className=glossary-text>lung volume</button> and decreasing pressure. This lower pressure results in air being moved into the lungs. During exhalation (see Figure 1), also called expiration, the ribcage moves back down and the diaphragm springs back to its original higher position. This decreases lung volume and increases air pressure in the lungs, causing air to move out of the lungs.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Two diagrams with arrows demonstrating lung volume increasing during inhalation and decreasing during exhalation
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Two diagrams with arrows demonstrating lung volume increasing during inhalation and decreasing during exhalation

pageData.text: During a normal breath, most CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> is removed and an adequate amount of oxygen is introduced into the lungs. When the breathing rhythm is too low and the amount of carbon dioxide concentration in the lungs is too high to be removed with normal breathing, it is called <button className=glossary-text>hypoventilation</button>. This buildup of CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> in the lungs results in an increase in blood acidity, which can lead to significant health issues.

<button className=glossary-text>Hyperventilation</button> describes when breathing is very quick and shallow. The shallowness of the breath does not allow oxygen to fully enter the lungs—only the air closest to the nose and mouth is refreshed, not the lower parts of the airways. This will lead to less air entering and leaving the lungs during each respiratory cycle. Someone who is hyperventilating has a reduced amount of oxygen in the blood, which also can cause serious health problems. When a hyperventilating person breathes into a paper bag, the amount of CO2 in the lungs increases, because the person is literally breathing back in the CO2 that was just exhaled. This increase triggers an automatic breathing reset in the body.

options.text: by establishing a pressure difference between the air inside the body and the air outside of the body
by equalizing the pressure between the air inside the body and the air outside the body
by establishing a pressure difference between the air in the lungs and the fluid in the pleural cavity
by establishing greater pressure in the chest cavity than in the abdominal cavity
by establishing a pressure difference between the alveoli and the chest cavity

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because air always moves from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure, breathing is accomplished by establishing a pressure difference between the air inside the body and the air outside of the body.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes the air pressure in the lungs during exhalation?

options.text: The air pressure in the lungs is greater than the air pressure outside the body.
The air pressure in the lungs is equal to the air pressure outside the body.
The air pressure in the lungs is less than the air pressure outside the body.
The air pressure in the lungs is equal to the air pressure beneath the diaphragm.
The air pressure in the lungs is less than the air pressure beneath the diaphragm.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In order to move air out of the lungs during exhalation, the air pressure in the lungs must be greater than the air pressure outside the body. Air always moves from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To ensure effective gas exchange, the body needs to ventilate the lungs and does so via the process of breathing. During inhalation (inspiration) the ribcage is pulled up and out, and the diaphragm is pulled down, increasing lung volume and decreasing pressure. This lower pressure results in air being moved into the lungs. During exhalation (expiration) the ribcage moves back down and the diaphragm springs back to its original higher position. This decreases lung volume and increases air pressure in the lungs, causing air to move out of the lungs.

img.alt: Figure 1: Two diagrams with arrows demonstrating lung volume increasing during inhalation and decreasing during exhalation

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To ensure effective gas exchange, the body needs to ventilate the lungs and does so via the process of breathing. During inhalation (inspiration) the ribcage is pulled up and out, and the diaphragm is pulled down, increasing lung volume and decreasing pressure. This lower pressure results in air being moved into the lungs. During exhalation (expiration) the ribcage moves back down and the diaphragm springs back to its original higher position. This decreases lung volume and increases air pressure in the lungs, causing air to move out of the lungs.

img.alt: Figure 1: Two diagrams with arrows demonstrating lung volume increasing during inhalation and decreasing during exhalation

pageData.subTitle: Elements of the Respiratory System
pageData.text: The body’s respiratory system is composed of several elements (see Figure 2). Air enters the body through the nose and mouth. Both air and food pass through the same space in the back of the mouth, the  <button className=glossary-text>pharynx</button>. Under the chin, the air passage splits from the food passage, and food travels to the stomach through the <button className=glossary-text>esophagus</button> while air enters first the <button className=glossary-text>larynx</button> before it goes into the  <button className=glossary-text>trachea</button>. To prevent food from also entering the larynx when a person swallows, a small flap called the <button className=glossary-text>epiglottis</button> closes the airway. The larynx, commonly called the “voice box,” is composed mainly of cartilage and voluntary muscle. It contains the vocal cords, membranous folds that vibrate to adjust the pitch and tone of vocalizations. The trachea is a tube-shaped structure with small rings of cartilage within its walls. The cartilage rings allow movement but are rigid enough to prevent the trachea from collapsing. In the chest cavity, the trachea splits into the left and right <button className=glossary-text>bronchus.</button>

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Labeled diagram of the parts of the respiratory system from the nose to the lungs
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Labeled diagram of the parts of the respiratory system from the nose to the lungs

pageData.text: These <button className=glossary-text>bronchi</button> conduct the air into the lungs. Deep within the lungs, the bronchi split into smaller tubes, the <button className=glossary-text>bronchioles</button>.The bronchioles end in small bubble-like pouches called <button className=glossary-text>alveoli</button>, which are the location for gas exchange between air and the bloodstream (see Figure 3). The alveoli are covered by a thin epithelial layer and are surrounded by <button className=glossary-text>capillaries</button>, blood vessels with extremely thin walls. Only the alveoli are capable of stretching and are responsible for increasing and decreasing  <button className=glossary-text>lung volume</button>. The lungs are ultimately organized into <button className=glossary-text>lobes</button>. The right lung has three lobes, while the left lung has only two since the heart is located slightly to the left and in between the lungs.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A cross-sectional view of a bronchus and a bronchiole with alveoli as well as a close-up of alveoli and a capillary, with arrows demonstrating gas exchange within alveoli
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A cross-sectional view of a bronchus and a bronchiole with alveoli as well as a close-up of alveoli and a capillary, with arrows demonstrating gas exchange within alveoli

pageData.subTitle: Lung Volume
pageData.text: There are some basic factors that influence . Males have larger lungs than females; the size of the person also affects lung volume, meaning larger people have larger lung volumes. Age is another factor contributing to lung volume. When a person gets older, the tissues in the lung become more rigid and lung volume decreases. Since these values vary, the rest of this discussion will reference average (see Table 1). The amount of air that is actually displaced is called the lung volume (see Table 2). Lung volumes and capacities are measured through clinical testing known as spirometry. Such tests are useful for diagnosing respiratory disorders such as those described on pages 7 and 8.

During a normal breath, which is one taken when at rest, about half a liter (about 2 cups) of air is drawn into and exhaled from the lungs. This quantity is called the <button className=glossary-text>tidal volume</button> (see Figure 4). In a healthy adult, about 12 to 16 breaths are taken per minute; the number of breaths taken per minute is called the  <button className=glossary-text>respiratory rate (RR)</button>. The amount of air that is inspired with each breath is only a fraction of the <button className=glossary-text>total lung capacity</button> (TLC), which is 5.8 liters for males and 4.2 liters for females (see <button className=resource-text>Table 1</button>). The TLC is defined as the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold as a result of the deepest possible inhalation. Even when taking the deepest breath and inhaling the maximum amount of air after a typical TV exhalation, males can inspire only a total of 3.5 liters of air, and females inspire only 2.4 liters. This is called the <button className=glossary-text>inspiratory capacity (IC)</button>, and the remaining capacity that is not inspired is called the <button className=glossary-text>functional residual capacity (FRC)</button>. The  <button className=glossary-text>vital capacity (VC)</button> is the maximum amount of air a person can expel from the lungs after a maximum inhalation.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Graph of the change in volume of the lung during normal breathing and deep breathing. The inspiratory reserve, tidal, expiratory reserve, and the residual volume regions are labeled. Functional reserve capacity is shown to be made up of ERV and RV values. Inspiratory capacity is shown to be the sum of the RV and TV values. Vital capacity is the sum of the ERV, TV, and RV values, and the total lung capacity is the sum of all lung volumes.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Graph of the change in volume of the lung during normal breathing and deep breathing. The inspiratory reserve, tidal, expiratory reserve, and the residual volume regions are labeled. Functional reserve capacity is shown to be made up of ERV and RV values. Inspiratory capacity is shown to be the sum of the RV and TV values. Vital capacity is the sum of the ERV, TV, and RV values, and the total lung capacity is the sum of all lung volumes.

pageData.text: As described previously, the <button className=glossary-text>tidal volume (TV)</button> is about 0.5 liters (see <button className=resource-text>Table 2</button>) in both males and females and is calculated from a normal breath taken while at ease and without moving. The amount of air that can be inhaled forcefully after a normal TV inhalation is called the <button className=glossary-text>inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)</button> and is 3.0 liters in males and 1.9 liters in females. More active individuals have larger tidal volumes and smaller inspiratory reserve volumes. Under extremely active conditions, the TV can be equal to the IRV.

Just as there is a maximum amount of air that can be inhaled, there also is a maximum exhalable amount of air after a typical TV exhalation, called the . The ERV is 1.1 liters for males and 0.7 liters for females. Comparing the IRV and the ERV reveals a larger inhalation volume than exhalation volume. The quantity of air left in the lungs after a forceful exhalation for males is 1.2 liters, while the remaining quantity for females is 1.1 liters. This is called the .Because there is a maximum volume, we can analyze the relationship between the different capacities using the formulas in Table 3.
To determine how efficient the lungs are, we can calculate the percentage of represented by the residual value:lung efficiency (%) = RV/TLC × 100%
Since the vital capacity changes with age and size, the following formulas can be used to estimate the vital capacity.

• For females: VC = (0.041 × height in cm) – (0.018 × age in years) – 2.69
  • For males: VC = (0.052 × height in cm) – (0.022 × age in years) – 3.6

pageData.question:
How can total lung capacity (TLC) be calculated?
  • Tidal volume (TV)
  • Vital capacity (VC)
  • Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
  • Inspiratory capacity (IC)
  • Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)
  • Functional residual capacity (FRC)
  • Residual volume (RV)

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Total lung capacity (TLC) is the maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation: TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between respiratory volumes and respiratory capacities?

options.text: Respiratory volumes can be used to determine respiratory capacities.
Respiratory measurements in men are called capacities, and in women they are called volumes.
Respiratory volume and respiratory capacity refer to the same measurement.
Respiratory capacities describe percentages of respiratory volumes.
Respiratory volumes are lower when respiratory capacities are higher and vice versa.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Respiratory volumes are used to calculate respiratory capacities.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Respiratory volumes are measurements of the amount of air in the lungs. These measurements can be combined in different ways to calculate respiratory capacities, which are gauges of respiratory function. Total lung capacity, for example, is the maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation. It is calculated as the sum of the four main respiratory volumes. Tidal volume (TV) is the amount drawn into and exhaled from the lungs during a typical breath when one is at rest. Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the amount that can be inhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation. Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the amount that can be exhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation. Residual volume (RV) is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a forceful exhalation.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Respiratory volumes are measurements of the amount of air in the lungs. These measurements can be combined in different ways to calculate respiratory capacities, which are gauges of respiratory function. Total lung capacity, for example, is the maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation. It is calculated as the sum of the four main respiratory volumes. Tidal volume (TV) is the amount drawn into and exhaled from the lungs during a typical breath when one is at rest. Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the amount that can be inhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation. Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the amount that can be exhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation. Residual volume (RV) is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a forceful exhalation.

pageData.subTitle: Conditions in the Respiratory System
pageData.text: The respiratory system is in direct contact with the air surrounding the human body. When we inhale, hairs within the nasal cavity filter out contaminants. Mucus layers in the nasal cavity moisten and heat the air. When inhaling through the mouth, the air is not filtered and moistened as effectively as when we inhale through the nose. Air entering the body contains contaminants that may be harmful to the body. Differences in temperature and humidity between the air outside the body and that within the body also can have detrimental effects. Contaminants and temperature differences can lead to various conditions in the respiratory system. To diagnose respiratory conditions, a stethoscope may be used to listen to a subject’s breathing sounds.

• During an asthmatic episode, the body reacts to real or perceived contaminants by activating the immune response. This leads to inflammation and subsequent constriction of the airways. Consequently, inflammation entering the lungs.

• Bronchitis refers to the inflammation of the mucus membranes within the . As a result of this inflammation, the airways, especially the , can become blocked, causing spasms in the lungs as they try to expel the perceived cause of the blockage. This is why the person coughs. When listening to the lungs of a person with this condition, the most common lung sounds are low-pitched wheezing and rough breathing sounds.
  • Pneumonia is commonly caused by an infection of the . This can be either bacterial or fungal and can occur in either one or both lungs. Pneumonia also can be caused by inhalation of chemicals or liquids. The most common lung sound associated with pneumonia is a high-pitched crackling that is similar to the sound of bacon being fried.
  • In emphysema, the alveoli are severely damaged—most times beyond repair. This condition reduces the surface area available for gas exchange with the blood. Since the alveoli also lose flexibility, inhalation and exhalation become less efficient. In severe cases, also becomes limited. Lung sounds in those with emphysema are reduced, because less air enters the lungs.

• COPD is a term used for a variety of diseases in which inhalation and exhalation are limited by either inflammation or physical obstruction. The hallmark of COPD is its chronic nature, i.e., it is typically a long-term complaint. The most common symptom is difficult inhalation or exhalation. A variety of lung sounds can be associated with COPD.
  • TB is caused by infection from a type of bacterium (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), which is transmitted through the air. The initial symptoms of TB resemble those of . After initial infection of the lungs, the bacteria may travel throughout the body, infecting other organs, such as the lymph nodes. As the lymph nodes are necessary components of the immune system, immunity is compromised. Infected tissues begin to die.
  • : Pulmonary edema develops when the blood vessels surrounding the rupture, thereby leaking blood into the alveolar sacs, which reduces lung function. The most common lung sound is similar to those of bubbles being blown underwater.
  • : In ILD, hardening of the interstitium (a network of fibrous tissues supporting the lungs) occurs. In such cases, the lungs cannot expand normally and it becomes difficult to breathe. Typically, a deep crackling sound is evident.

• Also referred to as a collapsed lung, this occurs when air enters the space between the lungs and the chest cavity, causing a buildup of pressure that leads to collapse of the alveoli. The person will have difficulty breathing, and lung sounds indicate limited to no airflow entering either one or both lungs.
  • Pleural effusion refers to an accumulation of fluid within the pleural. sac surrounding the lungs, which defines the pleural cavity (see ). This condition leads to rubbing of the pleural sac against the lungs. If left untreated, the blood vessels surrounding the lungs and alveoli become damaged. A sound similar to that of worn out windshield wipers on either a dry or a wet windshield is heard.

pageData.question: Which disease is associated with a sound like that of worn-out windshield wipers?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If pleural effusion is left untreated, the blood vessels surrounding the lungs and alveoli become damaged. A sound like that of worn-out windshield wipers on either a dry or a wet windshield is heard.

pageData.question: Which disease is associated with a high-pitched crackling sound?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Pneumonia is commonly caused by an infection, either bacterial or fungal, of the alveoli. The most common lung sound associated with pneumonia is a high-pitched crackling that is like the sound of bacon being fried.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To diagnose respiratory conditions, a stethoscope may be used to listen to a subject’s breathing sounds. Asthma results in the constriction of airways, causing a characteristic wheezing sound. Pulmonary edema causes blood to leak into the alveolar sacs, causing lung sounds similar to the sound of bubbles blown underwater. Pneumonia is commonly caused by an infection, either bacterial or fungal, of the alveoli. The most common lung sound associated with pneumonia is a high-pitched crackling that is like the sound of bacon being fried. Pleural effusion causes rubbing of the pleural sac against the lungs, which sounds like worn-out windshield wipers moving across a windshield.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To diagnose respiratory conditions, a stethoscope may be used to listen to a subject’s breathing sounds. Asthma results in the constriction of airways, causing a characteristic wheezing sound. Pulmonary edema causes blood to leak into the alveolar sacs, causing lung sounds similar to the sound of bubbles blown underwater. Pneumonia is commonly caused by an infection, either bacterial or fungal, of the alveoli. The most common lung sound associated with pneumonia is a high-pitched crackling that is like the sound of bacon being fried. Pleural effusion causes rubbing of the pleural sac against the lungs, which sounds like worn-out windshield wipers moving across a windshield.

pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, count your number of breaths per minute while seated for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the vital capacity.  In Activity 2, count your number of breaths per minute while standing for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the inspiratory reserve volume.  In Activity 3, count the number of breaths per minute after running for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the total lung capacity. Lastly, you will calculate your lung efficiency.
pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, count your number of breaths per minute while seated for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the vital capacity.  In Activity 2, count your number of breaths per minute while standing for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the inspiratory reserve volume.  In Activity 3, count the number of breaths per minute after running for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the total lung capacity. Lastly, you will calculate your lung efficiency.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity.

This investigation requires that individuals participate in a short period of physical activity. Please check with your health care provider before attempting the activities in this investigation. If you are not in good health or are unable to perform these activities, please alert the course instructor.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following lists, in order, the path taken by inhaled air?

options.text: pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveoli
larynx, pharynx, bronchi, trachea, alveoli, bronchioles
bronchioles, bronchi, trachea, larynx, pharynx, alveoli
trachea, pharynx, larynx, bronchi, bronchioles, alveoli
bronchi, alveoli, larynx, bronchioles, pharynx, trachea

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of inhalation?

options.text: The ribcage moves up and out, and the diaphragm moves down.
The ribcage moves down and in, and the diaphragm moves up.
The ribcage moves down and in, and the diaphragm moves down.
The ribcage moves up and out, and the diaphragm moves up.
The ribcage moves up and out, while the diaphragm stays in place.

Read the instructions.
Obtain all necessary materials.

In Activity 1, you will calculate the subject’s (either you or a test subject)  <button className=glossary-text>respiratory rate (RR)</button> while they are sitting. You will then calculate the subject’s  <button className=glossary-text>vital capacity (VC)</button>.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: If you have a partner, ask him or her to sit down comfortably for at least 2 minutes. If you don’t have a partner, sit down comfortably for 2 minutes.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will measure the normal  <button className=glossary-text>respiratory rate (RR)</button> while sitting.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Count the number of breaths your partner (or you) takes in 1 minute. Repeat at least 3 more times, and record your results in Data Table 1. Wait at least 1 minute between each trial.

Calculate the average number of breaths per minute, and record this in Data Table 1. You can calculate the average by adding the breaths per minute from each trial and dividing the sum by the number of trials.

Calculate the total volume of air that is drawn in for 1 minute while sitting. Use the following formula:
total volume of air in 1 minute = average number of breaths per minute × 0.5 liters
Record your answer in Data Table 1.

Calculate the vital capacity for the test subject, and record this in Data Table 1. Use a meter stick to find your partner’s height (or your height) in centimeters. Then use one of these formulas to determine the VC.

• For females: VC = (0.041 × height in cm) – (0.018 × age in years) – 2.69
  • For males: VC = (0.052 × height in cm) – (0.022 × age in years) – 3.6
In Activity 2, you will calculate the subject’s while they are standing. You will then use this data and the data from Activity 1 to calculate the subject’s .

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: If you have a partner, ask him or her to stand comfortably for at least 2 minutes. If you don’t have a partner, stand comfortably and relax for 2 minutes.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will measure the normal  <button className=glossary-text>respiratory rate (RR)</button> while standing.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Count the number of times your partner (or you) breathes in for 1 minute. Repeat at least 3 more times, and record your results in Data Table 2.

Calculate the average number of breaths per minute, and record this in Data Table 2. You can calculate the average by adding the breaths per minute from each trial and dividing the sum by the number of trials.

Calculate the total volume of air that is drawn in for 1 minute while standing. Use the following formula:
total volume of air in 1 minute = average number of breaths per minute × 0.5 liters
Record your answer in Data Table 2.
Use the VC calculated in Activity 1 and the formula below to calculate the . Write the IRV value in Data Table 2.

IRV = VC – ERV – TV
  • If your subject is a female, use ERV = 0.7 and TV = 0.5.
  • If your subject is a male, use ERV = 1.1 and TV = 0.5.
In Activity 3, you will calculate the subject’s after physical activity. You will then use this data and the data from Activity 2 to calculate the subject’s (TLC) and lung efficiency.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: If you have a partner, ask him or her to run in place for at least 2 minutes. If you don’t have a partner, run in place for 2 minutes.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will measure the normal  <button className=glossary-text>respiratory rate (RR)</button> while active.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Count the number of times your partner (or you) breathes in for 1 minute. Repeat at least 3 more times, and record your results in Data Table 3.

Calculate the average number of breaths per minute, and record this in Data Table 3. You can calculate the average by adding the number of breaths per minute from each trial and dividing the sum by the number of trials.

Calculate the total volume of air that is drawn in for 1 minute after running. Use the following formula:
total volume of air in 1 minute = average number of breaths per minute × 0.5 liters
Record your answer in Data Table 3.
Use the values from Activity 2 and the formula below to calculate the (TLC), and record your answer in Data Table 3.

TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV
  • If your subject is a female, use an RV of 1.1.
  • If your subject is a male, use an RV of 1.2.
Using your calculated data and the formula below, determine lung efficiency. Record the result in Data Table 3. lung efficiency (%) = RV/TLC × 100%

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
pageData.text: There is no disposal or cleanup necessary for this investigation.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.title: Data Table 1. Measuring Breathing While at Rest

header.text: Average number of breaths per minute

pageData.title: Data Table 2. Measuring Breathing While Standing

header.text: Average number of breaths per minute

text: Compare the average number of breaths per minute and volume per minute while at rest sitting vs. breathing while at rest standing. Is there a difference? Why or why not?

pageData.title: Data Table 3. Measuring Breathing After Running

header.text: Average number of breaths per minute

text: Compare the average number of breaths per minute and volume per minute while at rest (sitting and/or standing) vs. after running in place. Is there a difference? Why or why not?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Two diagrams with arrows demonstrating lung volume increasing during inhalation and decreasing during exhalation
Figure 2: Labeled diagram of the parts of the respiratory system from the nose to the lungs

pageData.content: Figure 3. Cross sections of a bronchiole and alveolus
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A cross-sectional view of a bronchus and a bronchiole with alveoli as well as a close-up of alveoli and a capillary, with arrows demonstrating gas exchange within alveoli

pageData.title: Table 1.
pageData.content: Table 1. Average lung volumes by sex

pageData.title: Table 2.
pageData.content: Table 2. Average lung capacities by sex
Figure 4. A lung volumes and capacities chart
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Graph of the change in volume of the lung during normal breathing and deep breathing. The inspiratory reserve, tidal, expiratory reserve, and the residual volume regions are labeled. Functional reserve capacity is shown to be made up of ERV and RV values. Inspiratory capacity is shown to be the sum of the RV and TV values. Vital capacity is the sum of the ERV, TV, and RV values, and the total lung capacity is the sum of all lung volumes.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, count your number of breaths per minute while seated for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the vital capacity.  In Activity 2, count your number of breaths per minute while standing for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the inspiratory reserve volume.  In Activity 3, count the number of breaths per minute after running for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate, the total volume of air drawn in for 1 minute, and the total lung capacity. Lastly, you will calculate your lung efficiency.

data.title: Adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
data.content: Is the main energy currency of the cell

data.title: Alveoli
data.content: Tiny air sacs in the lungs

data.title: Asthma
data.content: A chronic condition in which the airways become inflamed, narrow, and swell

data.title: Bronchiole
data.content: Tiny passageways in the lungs

data.title: Bronchitis
data.content: Inflammation of the mucus membranes within the bronchi

data.title: Bronchus (plural, bronchi)
data.content: Two large airways that branches from the trachea

data.title: Capillaries
data.content: The smallest blood vessels and have the thinnest walls

data.title: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
data.content: A term used for a variety of diseases in which inhalation and exhalation are limited by either inflammation or physical obstruction

data.title: Emphysema
data.content: The alveoli are severely damaged, this reduces the surface area avail-able for gas exchange with the blood

data.title: Epiglottis
data.content: A small flap that prevents food from entering the larynx

data.title: Erythrocyte
data.content: Red blood cells (RBC), without a nucleus, contains hemoglobin that transports oxygen and carbon dioxide to and from the tissues

data.title: Esophagus
data.content: A muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach

data.title: Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
data.content: The amount that can be exhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation.

data.title: Functional residual capacity (FRC)
data.content: The amount retained in the lungs after a normal TV exhalation: FRC = ERV + RV

data.title: Hemoglobin (Hb or Hgb)
data.content: A protein found in red blood cells that carries oxygen

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: Is a self-regulating process by which biological systems maintain stability while adjusting to environmental changes

data.title: Hyperventilation
data.content: “Over breathing”, breathing very quickly and shallow

data.title: Hypoventilation
data.content: Breathing rhythm is too low and the amount of carbon dioxide concentration in the lungs is too high to be removed with normal breathing

data.title: Inspiratory capacity (IC)
data.content: The maximum amount that can be inhaled after a typical TV exhalation: IC = TV + IRV

data.title: Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)
data.content: The amount that can be inhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation.

data.title: Interstitial lung disease (ILD)
data.content: Hardening of the interstitium (a network of fibrous tissues supporting the lungs) occurs

data.title: Larynx
data.content: “Voice box”, composed mainly of cartilage, voluntary muscle, and vocal cords, used for breathing, swallowing, and talking

data.title: Lobes
data.content: The lungs are ultimately organized into lobes, the right lung has three lobes, while the left lung has only two since the heart is located slightly to the left and in between the lungs

data.title: Lung capacity
data.content: Amount the lungs can hold

data.title: Lung volume
data.content: The amount of air that is displaced when breathing

data.title: Pharynx
data.content: The “throat”, a muscular passageway

data.title: Pleural effusion
data.content: An accumulation of fluid within the pleural sac surrounding the lungs, which defines the pleural cavity

data.title: Pneumonia
data.content: Common lung sound associated with pneumonia is a high-pitched crackling that is similar to the sound of bacon being fried

data.title: Pneumothorax
data.content: Referred to as a collapsed lung, this occurs when air enters the space between the lungs and the chest cavity, causing a buildup of pressure that leads to collapse of the alveoli

data.title: Pulmonary edema
data.content: Develops when the blood vessels surrounding the alveoli rupture, thereby leaking blood into the alveolar sacs, which reduces lung function

data.title: Residual volume (RV)
data.content: The amount of air remaining in the lungs after a forceful exhalation

data.title: Respiratory rate (RR)
data.content: The number of breaths per minute

data.title: Tidal volume (TV)
data.content: The amount drawn into and exhaled from the lungs during a typical breath when one is at rest

data.title: Total lung capacity (TLC)
data.content: The maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation: TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV

data.title: Trachea
data.content: The “windpipe”, a tube with C-shaped rings of cartilage, extends from the larynx to the bronchial tubes

data.title: Tuberculosis (TB)
data.content: Caused by infection from a type of bacterium (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), initial infection of the lungs, the bacteria may travel throughout the body, infecting other organs, such as the lymph nodes

data.title: Vital capacity (VC)
data.content: The maximum amount that can be expelled from the lungs after a forceful inhalation: VC = TV + IRV + ERV
